subtitle: Yes. All street drugs can cause problems for you and your baby
description: Yes. All street drugs can cause problems for you and your baby
title: Can street drugs hurt my baby?
content:
Created by BabyCenter

Street drugs are not safe, even in small amounts. If you use street drugs, including crack, it can damage your health, and your baby’s health. Now you are pregnant, it is a really good time to make a change so you can be healthy, and give your baby a good start in life. A doctor can help you can make this change. 

Call the government hotline for drug users: 132. By dialing this number you can stay incognito and find out how to get help.

All street drugs in your body reach your baby in your womb. They may affect your baby's growth in your womb. They can be life-threatening for you and your baby. They can cause health difficulties for your baby as she grows up. But do not quit suddenly, because this can lead to pregnancy loss. Talk to a doctor about how you can quit safely.   

Crack or cocaine can slow down your baby's growth and cause problems with learning and behaviour when she is older.

If you use heroin or tranquillisers, it is vital to get medical help as soon as you can. Heroin can cause pregnancy loss or premature birth, or your baby could be stillborn. Heroin can make it difficult for your baby to breathe just after she is born. Trying to quit on your own could be dangerous for you both. The safest way to quit is with medical help.

If you take street drugs during pregnancy, your baby may have withdrawal symptoms when she is born. Doctors can check her for signs of withdrawal, and treat her.

Call the government hotline for drug users: 132. By dialling this number you can stay incognito and find out how to get help.
